(1) ~(p1&p2&~p3)

When considering this formula, we are looking for the cases where the conjunction (p1&p2&~p3) is false, as applying the negation (~) in front flips the truth value of the conjunction.

- If we have p1 (âœ“), p2 (âœ“), and p3 (âœ“), then (p1&p2&~p3) = (âœ“&âœ“&~âœ“) = (âœ“&âœ“&x) = x. The negation of this conjunction is ~x = âœ“, meaning this is a true assignment.
- If we have p1 (âœ“), p2 (âœ“), and p3 (x), then (p1&p2&~p3) = (âœ“&âœ“&~x) = (âœ“&âœ“&âœ“) = âœ“. The negation of this conjunction is ~âœ“ = x, meaning this is a false assignment.
- If we have p1 (âœ“), p2 (x), and p3 (âœ“), then (p1&p2&~p3) = (âœ“&x&~âœ“) = (x&~âœ“) = x. The negation of this conjunction is ~x = âœ“, meaning this is a true assignment.
- If we have p1 (âœ“), p2 (x), and p3 (x), then (p1&p2&~p3) = (âœ“&x&~x) = (x&x) = x. The negation of this conjunction is ~x = âœ“, meaning this is a true assignment.
- If we have p1 (x), p2 (âœ“), and p3 (âœ“), then (p1&p2&~p3) = (x&âœ“&~âœ“) = x. The negation of this conjunction is ~x = âœ“, meaning this is a true assignment.
- If we have p1 (x), p2 (âœ“), and p3 (x), then (p1&p2&~p3) = (x&âœ“&~x) = x. The negation of this conjunction is ~x = âœ“, meaning this is a true assignment.
- If we have p1 (x), p2 (x), and p3 (âœ“), then (p1&p2&~p3) = (x&x&~âœ“) = x. The negation of this conjunction is ~x = âœ“, meaning this is a true assignment.
- If we have p1 (x), p2 (x), and p3 (x), then (p1&p2&~p3) = (x&x&~x) = x. The negation of this conjunction is ~x = âœ“, meaning this is a true assignment.

The True assignment for this formula is when the conjunction (p1&p2&~p3) is false. This occurs in all cases except when p3 is false (x) and p1 and p2 are true (âœ“), which makes the conjunction true and its negation false.

(2) (~p1&p2)=::>(p1=p3)

In this case, we need to determine the truth conditions under which the material implication ((~p1&p2)=::>(p1=p3)) holds.

For the material implication (if...then) to be true, either the antecedent (~p1&p2) is false or the consequent (p1=p3) must be true.

Firstly, let's consider the truth/falsity of the antecedent and consequent:

- Antecedent: The conjunction (~p1&p2) is true if and only if p1 is false and p2 is true.

- Consequent: The equivalence (p1=p3) is true if and only if p1 and p3 are both true or both false.

Given the complexities of analyzing all combinations manually, we'll use the derived principles from (1):

The material implication ((~p1&p2)=::>(p1=p3)) will be true if the antecedent (~p1&p2) is false or if the consequent (p1=p3) is true.

Thus, for formula (2):
For the consequent (p1=p3) to be true, we have the following assignment possibilities: p1 (âœ“), p3 (âœ“) or p1 (x), p3 (x).
For the antecedent (~p1&p2) to be false, we have the following assignment possibilities: p1 (âœ“), p2 (x) or p1 (âœ“), p2 (âœ“), or p1 (x), p2 (x).

Any combination other than p1 (âœ“), p2 (âœ“) leading to (p1=p3) (x) will result in the material implication being true.

Randomized cases of when it is false include: p1 (âœ“), p2 (âœ“), p3 (x)

For the antecedent to be false or consequent being true, we can understand that the implication will always be true save for the condition where p1 and p2 are true and p3 is false.

Thus, for formula (2):
T: x|x|x, x|x|âœ“, âœ“|x|x, x|âœ“|x, âœ“|x|âœ“, x|âœ“|âœ“, âœ“|âœ“|âœ“;
F: âœ“|âœ“|x.

(2) (~p1&p2)=::>(p1=p3) is T for all cases except when p1 (âœ“), p2 (âœ“), and p3 (x).

To solve the question, we will apply the Basic Equivalences rules one step at a time for both statements provided. 

(1) !(p>(p|q))&r
   = !(p>(p|q))&r                         # No change required
   = !(p>!(p&q))&r                        # Statement (2), equivalence rule 7 (swapping and knowing that p|q = !(p&q))
   = !(!(p&q)|q)&r                        # Statement (2), equivalence rule 10 (p>q = !p|q)
   = (!(p&q)|q)&r                         # Statement (2), equivalence rule 1 (double negation)
   = (!p | !q | q) & r                    # Statement (2), equivalence rule 6 (!A | B = !A & !B, applied in reverse)
   = !p & r                               # Statement (2), equivalence rule 8 (!A | A = 1)

So, for (1) the simplest result is ![p;r].

(2) p&(((p|q)&!p)>q)
   = p&(((p|q)&!p)>q)                     # No change required
   = p&(!(!(p|q)&!p)|q)                   # Statement (2), equivalence rule 10 (p>q = !p | q)
   = p&(!(!p&q)|q)                        # Statement (2), de Morgan's law (and in the reverse direction)
   = p&(!(!p&q)|q)                        # No change required
   = p&(p|q)                              # Statement (2), equivalence rule 8 (!(!A) = A) & rule 6
   = p                                     # Statement (2), equivalence rule 7 (A | (A & B) = A)

So, for (2) the simplest result is [p].

Therefore, the answer is [[!p;r];[p]].

For sub-question (1):
Using the given equivalences, we can analyze the given equivalence:
(1) ((p>q)&(p>r))::=::(p>(q|r))

Starting from the left side:
((p>q)&(p>r)) can be expanded using equivalence (10) as:
((!p | q) & (!p | r))

According to equivalence (4), we can rewrite this as:
(!p | (q & r))

Based on equivalence (10), the right side p>(q|r) can be written as:
!p | (q | r)

Since !p | (q | r) is equal to !p | (q | r), the left side is equivalent to the right side.

For sub-question (2):
Using the given equivalences, we can analyze the given equivalence:
(2) !(p=q)::=::(p|q)&!(p&q)

Starting from the left side:
!(p=q)
According to equivalence (11), p=q can be rewritten as:
(p > q) & (q > p)
Using equivalence (10), this can be written as:
(!p | q) & (!q | p)

Negating this (using equivalence (6)) yields:
!(p > q) | !(q > p)
Using equivalence (10) again, this can be rewritten as:
(p & !q) | (q & !p)

Starting from the right side:
(p|q)&!(p&q)
Using equivalence (6), !p & !q can be written as:
!(p & q)
This becomes:
(p | q) & (!(p & q))
This is exactly the same as the left side after negations are distributed (using equivalence (6)).

Thus both equivalences are valid.

To find the paired conjunctive terms and the denotation of the given expression \((\neg p \land \neg q \land r) \lor (\neg p \land q \land r)\), follow these steps:

### Given expression:
\[A = \left( \neg p \land \neg q \land r \right) \lor \left( \neg p \land q \land r \right)\]

### Step 1: Identify propositional variables
The propositional variables in the expression are \(p, q,\) and \(r\).

### Step 2: Identify paired conjunctive terms
The paired conjunctive forms in expression \(A\) are:
1. \(\neg p \land \neg q \land r\) 
2. \(\neg p \land q \land r\) 

### Step 3: Transform paired conjunctive terms into binary numbers
Transform the given paired conjunctive terms into their binary representation as follows:

1. \(\neg p \land \neg q \land r\) 
    - \(p=0, q=0, r=1\) 
    - Hexadecimal: 1 (Binary assignment 001)

2. \(\neg p \land q \land r\) 
    - \(p=0, q=1, r=1\) 
    - Hexadecimal: 3 (Binary assignment 011)

### Step 4: Denote the paired conjunctive terms
Denote the terms with their hexadecimal number assignments:

1. \(\neg p \land \neg q \land r\) becomes \(m_1\)
2. \(\neg p \land q \land r\) becomes \(m_3\)

### Step 5: Format the answer
The given expression can be denoted in the paired conjunctive terms as follows:
\[A = m_1 \lor m_3\]

### Final Answer:
\[[[paired conjunctive terms:m_1, m_3]; [denoted:A=m_1 \lor m_3]]\]

First, we analyze the given expression (pâˆ¨Â¬qâˆ¨r)^(Â¬pâˆ¨Â¬qâˆ¨r) to identify the paired disjunctive terms.

The expression itself is in conjunctive normal form (CNF), specifically a conjunction of two clauses:
- One clause is (pâˆ¨Â¬qâˆ¨r)
- The other clause is (Â¬pâˆ¨Â¬qâˆ¨r)

To convert this into paired disjunctive terms, we need to consider the normal disjunctive form (DNF) of the entire expression.

Given that we have three propositional variables (p, q, r), the total number of paired conjunctive terms will be \(2^3 = 8\), each corresponding to a unique binary number from 000 to 111 (or 0 to 7 in decimal, and from 0 to 7 in hexadecimal).

However, when dealing with conjunctive normal forms applied to paired disjunctive terms, the focus is on identifying which truth assignments (or which binary numbers) our expressions make false, as the negation of these will be the relevant paired disjunctive terms.

Let's determine the truth assignments that make each individual clause false:
- (pâˆ¨Â¬qâˆ¨r) will be false if p, Â¬q, and r are false -> Â¬pâˆ§qâˆ§Â¬r -> binary number is 010, hexadecimal number is 2.
- (Â¬pâˆ¨Â¬qâˆ¨r) will be false if Â¬p, Â¬q, and r are false -> pâˆ§qâˆ§Â¬r -> binary number is 110, hexadecimal number is 6.

Now let's consider the full expression (pâˆ¨Â¬qâˆ¨r)^(Â¬pâˆ¨Â¬qâˆ¨r). The truth assignments that make the full expression false are when both clauses are false simultaneously:
- At the same time, both clauses will be false if p=true, q=true, and r=false -> pâˆ§qâˆ§Â¬r -> binary number is 110, hexadecimal number is 6.

Thus, the truth assignment that makes our full expression false corresponds to a binary number of 110, which corresponds to a hexadecimal value of 6. This means the paired disjunctive term that makes our full expression false is referred to as \( M6 \).

To determine the paired disjunctive terms for the given expression we have to recognize that since all paired disjunctive terms are Boolean negations to the truth assignments that make a given clause false, we have only identified an instance where the complex clause becomes false, not the paired disjunctive terms in the clause before negation.

However, in the context of the given instruction, applying the given rule, we can see that (pâˆ¨Â¬qâˆ¨r)^(Â¬pâˆ¨Â¬qâˆ¨r) results in a minimum of false assignments, which is consequently represented by only one paired disjunctive term \(M_6\), indicating the possible binary assignment 110 (or hex 6) makes the expression false in full.

Thus, representing the given clause in the format asked by the question, we get the following:

Paired disjunctive terms: [M6],
Denotation as per rule provided: [M6].

The answer to the question would be represented as:

(Â¬p âˆ§ Â¬q âˆ§ r) âˆ¨ (Â¬p âˆ§ q âˆ§ Â¬r) âˆ¨ (p âˆ§ Â¬q âˆ§ r)

m1 âˆ¨ m2 âˆ¨ m5

Explanation: According to the Resolution rule, two clauses can be resolved if they have complementary literals. Here, C1 = p âˆ¨ q and C2 = p âˆ¨ r do not have any complementary literals to resolve upon. Both C1 and C2 contain p, but it is the same literal (not complemented); therefore, they cannot be resolved.

Given C1 = p âˆ¨ Â¬q âˆ¨ r âˆ¨ Â¬s and C2 = s, we want to find dispel(C1, C2).

First, note that the literal Â¬s is present in C1 and its complement s is in C2. These literals can be resolved according to the given resolution rule.

Following the rule:

dispel(C1, C2) = dispel(p âˆ¨ Â¬q âˆ¨ r âˆ¨ Â¬s, s)

= dispel(p âˆ¨ Â¬q âˆ¨ r, []) (since Â¬s and s eliminate each other)

The resulting clause after resolution is p âˆ¨ Â¬q âˆ¨ r, as Â¬s and s cancel each other out.

Thus, dispel(C1, C2) = [p âˆ¨ Â¬q âˆ¨ r].

Answer: [p âˆ¨ Â¬q âˆ¨ r].

To solve the given question using the resolution algorithm, first, we identify the conjunctive normal form (CNF) given:

S = (Â¬p âˆ¨ q) âˆ§ (p âˆ¨ q) âˆ§ (q)

In our notation:
S = {(Â¬p âˆ¨ q), (p âˆ¨ q), (q)}

Let's start executing the algorithm step by step.

**Step 1**: Initialization
- S0 = {}, S2 = {}, S1 = {(Â¬p âˆ¨ q), (p âˆ¨ q), (q)}

**Step 2**: Resolve clauses in S0 and S1
- Since S0 is empty, we skip these resolutions.

**Step 3**: Resolve clauses in S1
- Take (Â¬p âˆ¨ q) and (p âˆ¨ q), we can resolve these clauses. Since L=Â¬p and L'=p, dispel(C1, C2) = q, as q âˆ¨ q = q. 
- Now S2 considers q, but it was already contained in S1, so we don't add it.
- Now take (Â¬p âˆ¨ q) and (q), there is nothing to be resolved here.
- Then take (p âˆ¨ q) and (q), again nothing to be resolved.
  
**Check S2**: S2 contains no new elements, so we don't add anything. In the next iteration, S2 should be checked again. Therefore, we add S1 to S0, S1 becomes S2 (which is currently empty), and S2 is cleared.

Since no new clauses have been added, and we end up with S2 empty, no further iterations need to take place. We have found that every clause in S is satisfiable (due to the presence of q in every possible case).

**Output**: "Plausible".

**Number of Cycles**: 1 (Only one full cycle was necessary to determine the output).

To solve the given question using the resolution algorithm, we first identify the conjunctive normal form (CNF) S:

S = (pâˆ¨q)âˆ§(pâˆ¨Â¬q)âˆ§(Â¬pâˆ¨r)

Step 3 (Initialization):
- S0 = {} (empty set)
- S1 = {(pâˆ¨q), (pâˆ¨Â¬q), (Â¬pâˆ¨r)}
- S2 = {} (empty set)

Step 3 (Resolve clauses in S0 and S1):
Since S0 is empty, no resolution is possible with the current clauses in S1. Moving on to resolve clauses in S1.

Step 3 (Resolve clauses in S1):
We resolve each pair of clauses in S1. Let's resolve each pair by calculating dispel(C1, C2).

- dispel((pâˆ¨q), (pâˆ¨Â¬q)) = q âˆ¨ Â¬q
    - The result is q âˆ¨ Â¬q, but since this is a tautology (always true), it's not useful for the process. No need to add it to S2.

- dispel((pâˆ¨q), (Â¬pâˆ¨r)) = q âˆ¨ r
    - If this clause is not in S0 or S1, it's added to S2.

- dispel((pâˆ¨Â¬q), (Â¬pâˆ¨r)) = r âˆ¨ Â¬q
    - If this clause is not in S0 or S1, it's added to S2.

Considering the results of the dispel function, S2 now contains {qâˆ¨r, râˆ¨Â¬q}.

Step 3 (Check S2):
Since S2 is not empty, S2 will be added to S1 for the next iteration. Therefore:
- S0 still contains {} (empty set)
- S1 now contains {qâˆ¨r, râˆ¨Â¬q}
- S2 has been cleared (S2 = {})

Step 3 (Resolve clauses in S1):
Once again, resolving the clauses in S1:
- dispel((qâˆ¨r), (râˆ¨Â¬q)) = r âˆ¨ q
    - Since both clauses in this step resulted in the same literal and its negation combined with another literal, no useful information is added. No need to add it to S2 as it's already represented.

No new elements are added to S2 after resolving the clauses in S1.

Step 3 (Check S2):
Since S2 is empty, we have reached the termination condition.

- The output is "Plausible".
- Since no clause forcing an impossibility was found, the formula is satisfiable.

  "FJ(fJ(x, aâ€²), y) â†’ FJ(gJ(x, y), z)",
  "(x + 0 = y) â†’ (x * y = z)"
]

Given the formula âˆ€xF(g(x,a),x)â†’F(x,y), we will find its implementation under J following the provided rules:

1. Entity set E = N (natural numbers).
2. Replace entity constant a with its assignment aâ€² = 0.
3. Replace function symbol g with its implementation gJ(x, y) = x * y.
4. Replace predicate symbol F with its implementation FJ(x, y) denoting x = y.

The provided formula can be rewritten as:
\[ \forall x \big( F(g(x, a), x) \rightarrow F(x, y) \big) \]

After replacing a with \(a'\) = 0, the formula becomes:
\[ \forall x \big( F(g(x, 0), x) \rightarrow F(x, y) \big) \]

After replacing g with its implementation \(g_J(x, y) = x * y\), the formula becomes:
\[ \forall x \big( F((x * 0), x) \rightarrow F(x, y) \big) \]

Since any number multiplied by 0 gives 0 and because the implementation of predicate F(x, y) denotes \(x = y\), it becomes necessary to consider the semantics implied by these expressions. The (x * 0) portion results in 0 for any number x, and comparing this result to x â€” \(F_J(0, x)\) â€” only holds true when x equals 0, which provides a specific case, but as it's part of a universally quantified statement, we must consider the truth value for all x in E (which are all natural numbers).

Therefore, the implementation \(B_J\) can now be written under the understanding that when \(x \ne 0\), \(F_J(0, x)\) is false, and when \(x = 0\), \(F_J(0, x)\) is true. However, as the formula involves a conditional \(\rightarrow\) and is universally quantified over x, we evaluate the truth of the entire statement.

The formula is true when \(x = 0\) since \(F_J(x, y)\) will also be true when \(x = y = 0\) and is trivially true for other values of y since \(x * 0 = 0\) does not equal any other natural number x â€” this forces the antecedent to always be false for \(x \ne 0\), making the entire conditional statement true by the semantics of \(\rightarrow\) in propositional logic, as a false antecedent always results in a true statement.

Thus, the fully considered implementation under J, accounting for the domain and meaning of its components, represents:
\[ \forall x \in \mathbb{N} \big( (x * 0) = x \rightarrow x = y \big) \]

Given the logical and functional considerations, the formula's implementation under J denoted as \(B_J\), signifies the truth-value of the original formula for every \(x \in \mathbb{N}\), and comparing x to y in the context specified.

The answer in the specified [[]] format would be:
\[
[\forall x \in \mathbb{N} \big((x * 0) = x \rightarrow x = y \big)]
\]

response:
The given logical statements can be rewritten to fit the syllogistic form as follows:

1. âˆ€Pâ‡’M (First Premise)
2. âˆ€Mâ‡’Â¬S (Second Premise)
3. âˆ´ âˆ€Sâ‡’Â¬P (Conclusion)

Let's analyze the form of the syllogism. The major premise is "âˆ€Pâ‡’M", the minor premise is "âˆ€Mâ‡’Â¬S", and the conclusion is "âˆ€Sâ‡’Â¬P". We can translate this into a syllogistic form by substituting P, M, and S as the predicates in the forms provided. The argument can be represented as:

1. P()M (First Premise)
2. M()S (Second Premise)
3. âˆ´ S()P (Conclusion)

Observing the provided premises and conclusion, the form matches Figure III:

1. M()P (First Premise: âˆ€Pâ‡’M, which fits M()P where () = A)
2. M()S (Second Premise: âˆ€Mâ‡’Â¬S, which fits M()S where () = E)
3. âˆ´ S()P (Conclusion: âˆ€Sâ‡’Â¬P, which fits S()P where () = O)

Given that "M()P" has the form of a universal affirmative (A), "M()S" has the form of a universal negative (E), and the conclusion "S()P" has the form of a particular negative (O), the valid mood in Figure III that matches this format is "EIO".

Therefore, the argument corresponds to the format [[III];[EIO]].

The given syllogism follows the form of Figure II, where the major premise is P()M, the minor premise is SEM, and the conclusion is S()P. The minor premise SEM indicates an "O" operation (i.e., âˆƒSâ‡’Â¬M). To proceed, we need to determine the valid mood that fits the given premises and conclusion.

Looking at Figure II, the valid moods that include "O" operation in the minor premise are EIO and AOO. However, to correctly complete the given syllogism, we need to ensure that the conclusion S()P also aligns with the valid mood.

Since the minor term "S" is negated in relation to "M" in the minor premise (SEM), for the conclusion S()P to logically follow, the major term "P" must also be negatively related to "S". This indicates that the major premise P()M should not negate "P" in relation to "M", ruling out EAE and AEE, leaving EIO and AOO as the potential valid moods.

Given that the conclusion S()P also presents a negative relation (as implied from SEM leading to a negative conclusion about P), the correct mood to fit the premises and conclusion is EIO.

### Answer:
[EIO;[P;M];[SEM];[S;Â¬P]]

Given the situation where a proposition \(p\) is the consensus of the group \(G\) but the individual Alice (denoted as \(i\) for simplicity in this context) doubts this proposition, the logical expressions based on the Cognitive Logic Rule can be written in the following format considering Cognitive Logic Axioms and Symbol Definitions:

\[
[\neg B_ip \land G_p]
\]

This expression can be broken down to reflect the logical scenario at hand. The doubt aspect from Alice is represented as \(\neg B_ip\), which utilizes the negation of the belief (\(\neg B_p\)) to indicate that Alice does not firmly believe in the proposition \(p\).

The consensus part, where \(p\) is a common belief in the group \(G\), is expressed as \(G_p\). Within this context, \(G_p\) stands for the fact that all members of the group, including Alice before her doubt began, collectively believe in \(p\). Note that while Alice's belief state regarding \(p\) has changed to doubt, we are specifically acknowledging the consensus notion that \(p\) was commonly believed irrespective of individual deviations.

Thus, the logical expression conveys the paradoxical or at least the anomalous situation in which Alice's current disbelief in \(p\) stands in contrast to the proposition being commonly believed in her group. The inclusion of both elements in the logical expression properly encapsulates the nuance of this specific scenario as defined within the Cognitive Logic framework.

C. ê™® method

The passage describes a scenario where the presence of uranium does not account for the observed high radioactivity in the remaining samples after uranium extraction. This suggests a positive group where the presence of an unknown radioactive element (S) corresponds to high radioactivity (P), and a negative group where uranium alone (S is absent) does not produce the same level of radioactivity (P is absent). Therefore, the passage is consistent with the ê™® method. 

[[C]]

Given that 4 out of 5 randomly selected days had an AQI below 50, we can apply the P-Generalization rule to infer the proportion of days in the city when the AQI was below 50.

Here:
- Attribute `A`: AQI below 50
- `k` (number of individuals in the sample with the attribute): 4
- `n` (total number of individuals in the sample): 5

Using the P-Generalization Rule symbolization:
\[ P(A, k, n) \Rightarrow Pr(A) â‰ˆ \frac{k}{n} \]

\[ Pr(A) â‰ˆ \frac{4}{5} = 0.8 \]

Converting to percentage:

\[ 0.8 = 80\% \]

Therefore, the answer is:

\[ [80\%] \]

Given the scenario, we have:

- `n` (sample size) = 50
- `k` (number of individuals possessing attribute A, which in this case is being defective) = 2
- Total population size is not directly used in P-Generalization, but it's given as 1,000 for context.

Using the P-Generalization rule:

\[ \text{If } P(A, k, n), \text{ then } Pr(A) \approx \frac{k}{n}. \]

We find:

\[ Pr(\text{Defective}) \approx \frac{2}{50} = \frac{2}{50} = 0.04 = 4\%. \]

Therefore, estimating the rate of defective products for the entire batch:

\[ \boxed{4\%} \]

B

The scenario described fits the BC Paradox. The holomorphic hypothesis "All swans are white" (âˆ€x(S(x) â†’ W(x))) is being corroborated by seeing a white swan (W(a)âˆ§S(a) confirms âˆ€x(S(x) â†’ W(x))), which aligns with the confirmation standard. Additionally, according to the equivalence condition, seeing a white object that is not a swan (W(b)âˆ§Â¬S(b)) also confirms the holomorphic hypothesis (âˆ€x(S(x) â†’ W(x)) is equivalent to âˆ€x(Â¬W(x)â†’Â¬S(x))). This creates a situation where confirmation standards might lead to contradictory outcomes, which is characteristic of the BC Paradox.

C

Explanation:

The given situation fits the description of the LS Paradox. Here, we have the following hypotheses:
1. r_1: All birds fly (which is reasonable due to common observation, although oversimplified).
2. r_2: Penguins are birds (which is a fact).
3. r_3: However, penguins do not fly (which is also a fact, contradicting the first hypothesis).

In this case:
- r_1: "All birds fly" is a reasonably accepted hypothesis; however, it is oversimplified.
- r_2: "Penguins are birds" is a fact and a reasonably accepted hypothesis.
- r_3: "However, penguins do not fly" is also a fact, and serves as a piece of evidence that contradicts r_1.

So the conjunction of the propositions r_1 and r_2 contradicts r_3, illustrating the LS paradox.

[[C]]

C. LS Paradox

The given expression (p â†’ q) âˆ§ (Â¬p â†’ q) represents the LS Paradox because it involves reasoning about the consequences of multiple hypotheses (q under different conditions) and how they relate to an event (p or Â¬p). If q is seen as a reasonable conclusion when p is true and also when p is not true, but q contradicts another reasonable hypothesis, it falls under the conditions of the LS Paradox where the reasonableness of hypotheses needs to be reassessed to avoid contradictions. Therefore, the answer is [[C]].
